item.title: About
item.description:
Hello! My name is Michael Wooley. I am an economics graduate student currently searching for positions in industry. My current interests are in deep learning, numerical problems, and programming (broadly conceived). However, I am always up for learning about something new. As an economist I worked on problems in macroeconomics and public economics.

 wm.wooley@gmail.com
 GitHub
 LinkedIn Below you will find some links to my papers and projects. Please feel free to reach out to learn more.

Here is my cv.

Projects

  • Unnamed Table Reading Project (Current) Check back soon for details.
  • Shooting Backwards Developed novel solution to non-linear, non-stationary banking crisis model by Kiyotaki and Gertler (2015)
    • Time to solution cut 15x
    • Used MATLAB symbolic algebra to demonstrate backwards-in-time solution a quartic polynomial with analytic solution (impossible with pen and paper)
    • Used spline interpolation to infer solution to inner loop.
  • name.com.bo A search engine for finding and buying a cutesy website name using non-standard domains (e.g. “.com.bo” is the “.com” SLD for the Bolivian country code)
    • Implemented efficient search over 134k words in CMU pronunciation dictionary to find phonetic matches (e.g. “Michael Wooley” → michaelwoo.ly)

Selected Papers and Presentations

  1. “Fiscal Centralization: Theory and Evidence from the Great Depression”, forthcoming. American Economic Journal: Economic Policy. (with Daniele Coen-Pirani) [Supplements]
  2. “Labor Market Consequences of Graduating During a Recession: The Case of the Termites”, 2017. [Supplements]
  3. “Monetary Policy in an Economy with Production Networks”, 2017. (Northwestern Macro Lunch)
  4. “State-Local Centralization During the Great Depression: A Case Study of Ohio”, 2013. [First Prize, 2013 Ossip Awards for Excellence in Undergraduate Writing. University of Pittsburgh.]
  5. “Pitt and the Worker Rights Consortium: An Argument for Affiliation”, 2013. [On behalf of Pitt #NoSweat Coalition Against Sweatshop Labor]

Resume/CV

One thing that I’ve found is that many people have widely divergent ideas of what constitutes a good resume or cv. In the hopes of making it easy to find the right information fast, I am posting three versions of my resume/cv:

  1. Business (Longer)
  2. Business/“Data Scientist” (Shorter)
  3. Academic CV

About This Site

This site was built with Hugo, a static website generator. It is hosted on GitHub.

The basic theme is based on tufte-css, a stylesheet based on the Edward Tufte’s books and handouts. The css was converted into a full-blown Hugo theme by the creators of hugo-tufte.

I have begun an overhaul of the hugo-tufte theme that includes:

  • Inline and marginal images and divs with captioning.
  • Sharing buttons (work in progress).
  • Easy addition of custom javascript and css for demos.
  • Various tweaks to the layouts and css.

Once I make some more progress I’ll look into merging these changes with hugo-tufte. In the meantime, I’d be happy to share over email.
